title: Measurement Errors in R
text: International Vocabulary Metrology (VIM) defines “property phenomenon, body, substance, property magnitude can expressed number reference”, typically number , attributed experimentally obtained via measurement procedure, reference . Additionally, quantity value must accommodate indication quality measurement, quantifiable attribute known . Guide Expression Uncertainty Measurement (GUM) defines “parameter, associated result measurement, characterises dispersion values reasonably attributed measurand” . Uncertainty can mainly classified , result direct measurement (e.g., electrical voltage measured voltmeter, current measured amperemeter), , result indirect measurement (.e., standard uncertainty result derived number quantities means mathematical relationship; e.g., electrical power product voltage current). Therefore, provided set quantities known uncertainties, process obtaining uncertainty derived measurement called . Traditionally, computational systems treated three components (quantity values, measurement units uncertainty) separately. Data consisted bare numbers, mathematical operations applied solely. Units just metadata, uncertainty propagation unpleasant task requiring additional effort complex operations. Nowadays though, many software libraries formalised method including units within scope mathematical operations, thus preserving dimensional correctness protecting us computing nonsensical combinations quantities. However, libraries rarely integrate uncertainty handling propagation . Within R environment, package defines class associating unit metadata numeric vectors, enables transparent quantity derivation, simplification conversion. approach comfortable way managing units added advantage eliminating entire class potential programming mistakes. Unfortunately, neither package address integration uncertainties quantity calculus. article presents , package defines framework associating uncertainty metadata R vectors, matrices arrays, thus providing transparent, lightweight automated propagation uncertainty. implementation also enables ongoing developments integrating units uncertainty handling complete solution.

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: two main methods propagation uncertainty: (TSM) (MCM). TSM, also called , based Taylor expansion mathematical expression produces output variables. MCM, can deal generalised input distributions propagates uncertainty Monte Carlo simulation.

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: TSM flexible simple method propagation uncertainty offers good degree approximation cases. following, provide brief description. full derivation, discussion examples can found . Mathematically, indirect measurement obtained function \(n\) direct indirect measurements, \(Y = f(X_1, ..., X_n)\), distribution \(X_n\) unknown priori. Usually, sources random variability many, independent probably unknown well. Thus, central limit theorem establishes addition sufficiently large number random variables tends normal distribution. result, states \(X_n\) normally distributed. presumes linearity, .e., \(f\) can approximated first-order Taylor series expansion around \(\mu_{X_n}\) (see Figure \(\ref{propagation}\)). , given set \(n\) input variables \(X\) set \(m\) output variables \(Y\), first-order establishes \[\begin{equation}\Sigma_Y = J_X \Sigma_X J_X^T\label{eq:prop-law}\end{equation}\] \(\Sigma\) covariance matrix \(J\) Jacobian operator. Illustration linearity interval \(\pm\) one standard deviation around mean. practice, recommended GUM , first-order approximation good even \(f\) non-linear, provided non-linearity negligible compared magnitude uncertainty, .e., \(\E[f(X)]\approx f(\E[X])\). Also, weaker condition distribution-free: assumptions needed probability density functions (PDF) \(X_n\), although must reasonably symmetric. consider Equation \(\eqref{eq:prop-law}\) pairwise computations, .e., \(Y = f(X_1, X_2)\), can write propagation uncertainty \(\sigma_Y\) follows: \[\begin{equation}\label{eq:prop-var}   \sigma_Y^2 = \left(\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial X_1^2}\right)^2 \sigma_{X_1}^2 +                \left(\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial X_2^2}\right)^2 \sigma_{X_2}^2 +                2 \frac{\partial f \partial f}{\partial X_1 \partial X_2} \sigma_{X_1 X_2} \end{equation}\] cross-covariances output \(Y\) variable \(Z\) can simplified follows: \[\begin{equation}\label{eq:prop-covar}   \sigma_{Y Z} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial X_1} \sigma_{X_1 Z} +                  \frac{\partial f}{\partial X_2} \sigma_{X_2 Z} \end{equation}\] , notably, \(Z=X_i\), one covariances results \(\sigma_{X_i}^2\). Finally, sake completeness, correlation coefficient can obtained \(r_{Y Z} = \sigma_{Y Z} / (\sigma_{Y}\sigma_{Z})\).

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: MCM based principles underlying TSM. based propagation PDFs input variables \(X_n\) performing random sampling evaluating model considered. Thus, method constrained TSM assumptions, explicitly determines PDF output quantity \(Y\), makes general approach applies broader set problems. details method, well comparison TSM discussion applicability methods, reader may refer Supplement 1 GUM .

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: GUM defines four ways reporting standard uncertainty combined standard uncertainty. instance, reported quantity assumed mass \(m_S\) nominal value 100 g: \(m_S = 100.02147\) g (combined standard uncertainty) \(u_c\) = 0.35 mg. \(m_S = 100.02147(35)\) g, number parentheses numerical value (combined standard uncertainty) \(u_c\) referred corresponding last digits quoted result. \(m_S = 100.02147(0.00035)\) g, number parentheses numerical value (combined standard uncertainty) \(u_c\) expressed unit quoted result. \(m_S = (100.02147 \pm 0.00035)\) g, number following symbol \(\pm\) numerical value (combined standard uncertainty) \(u_c\) confidence interval. Schemes (2, 3) (4) referred notation notation respectively throughout document. Although (4) extended notation, GUM explicitly discourages use prevent confusion confidence intervals.

Unfortunately, case , packages limited work expressions, solve issue requiring separate workflow deal uncertainties. package focuses uncertainty analysis spatial environmental modelling, spatial cross-correlation variables becomes important. uncertainty described probability distributions propagated using MCM. Finally, package takes idea one step providing S4-based object-oriented implementation probability distributions, one can operate arithmetically apply mathematical functions. implements kinds probability distributions methods computing distribution derived quantities. Also, base whole family packages, , , , , . packages provide excellent tools uncertainty analysis propagation. However, none addresses issue integrated workflow, unit metadata assigning units directly R vectors, matrices arrays. result, units can added existing R computation straightforward way. hand, existing tools uncertainty propagation require building specific expressions data structures, work extract results report properly, appropriate number significant digits.

previous_headings: Automated uncertainty handling in R: the package
what: Example: Simultaneous resistance and reactance measurement
title: Measurement Errors in R
text: Annex H.2 GUM : resistance \(R\) reactance \(X\) circuit element determined measuring amplitude \(V\) sinusoidally-alternating potential difference across terminals, amplitude \(\) alternating current passing , phase-shift angle \(\phi\) alternating potential difference relative alternating current. measurands (resistance \(R\), reactance \(X\) impedance \(Z\)) related input quantities (\(V\), \(\), \(phi\)) Ohm’s law: \[\begin{equation}   R = \frac{V}{}\cos\phi; \qquad X = \frac{V}{}\sin\phi; \qquad Z = \frac{V}{} \end{equation}\] Five simultaneous observations input variable provided (Table H.2 GUM), included dataset . First, need obtain mean input values set correlations measurements. , compute measurands examine correlations . results agree reported GUM:
code: V   <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$V)) I   <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$I)) phi <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$phi))  correl(V, I)   <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(V, I)) correl(V, phi) <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(V, phi)) correl(I, phi) <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(I, phi))  print(R <- (V / I) * cos(phi), digits = 2, notation = "plus-minus") ## 127.732 ± 0.071 print(X <- (V / I) * sin(phi), digits = 3, notation = "plus-minus") ## 219.847 ± 0.296 print(Z <- (V / I), digits = 3, notation = "plus-minus") ## 254.260 ± 0.236 correl(R, X); correl(R, Z); correl(X, Z) ## [1] -0.5884298 ## [1] -0.4852592 ## [1] 0.9925116

previous_headings: Automated uncertainty handling in R: the package
title: Measurement Errors in R
text: Annex H.3 GUM : thermometer calibrated comparing \(n=11\) temperature readings \(t_k\) thermometer […] corresponding known reference temperatures \(t_{R,k}\) temperature range 21 \(^\circ\)C 27 \(^\circ\)C obtain corrections \(b_k=t_{R,k}-t_k\) readings. Measured temperatures corrections (Table H.6 GUM), included dataset , related linear calibration curve: \[\begin{equation}   b(t) = y_1 + y_2 (t - t_0) \end{equation}\] following, first fit linear model reference temperature \(t_0=20\) \(^\circ\)C. , extract coefficients, assign uncertainty correlation . Finally, compute predicted correction \(b(30)\), agrees value reported GUM:
code: fit <- lm(bk ~ I(tk - 20), data = GUM.H.3)  y1 <- set_errors(coef(fit)[1], sqrt(vcov(fit)[1, 1])) y2 <- set_errors(coef(fit)[2], sqrt(vcov(fit)[2, 2])) covar(y1, y2) <- vcov(fit)[1, 2]  print(b.30 <- y1 + y2 * set_errors(30 - 20), digits = 2, notation = "plus-minus") ## -0.1494 ± 0.0041

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: package provides means defining numeric vectors, matrices arrays errors R, well operate transparent way. Propagation uncertainty implements commonly used first-order TSM formula Equation \(\eqref{eq:prop-law}\). method pre-computed expanded operation S3 groups , instead differentiating symbolic expressions demand using functions packages task. advantages approach twofold. one hand, faster, involve simulation symbolic computation, lightweight terms package dependencies. Another advantage built-consistent formally sound representation measurements errors, rounding uncertainty one significant digit default supporting two widely used notations: (e.g., \(5.00(1)\)) (e.g., \(5.00 \pm 0.01\)). notations applied single numbers data frames, well data frames package. Full support provided , well matrices arrays. However, operations data structures may drop uncertainties (.e., object class attributes). specifically, six common data wrangling operations: row subsetting, row ordering, column transformation, row aggregation, column joining (un)pivoting. Table \(\ref{tab:compat}\) shows correspondence operations R base functions, well compatibility . Overall, fully compatible data wrangling operations embed R base, functions mainly based subsetting generics, provides corresponding S3 methods. Nonetheless, special attention must paid aggregations, store partial results lists finally simplified. simplification made , drops input attributes, including custom classes. However, aggregation functions provide argument (sometimes ), set , prevents destructive simplification, lists returned. lists can simplified non-destructively calling .
code: unlist <- function(x) if (is.list(x)) do.call(c, x) else x iris.e.agg <- aggregate(. ~ Species, data = iris.e, mean, simplify=FALSE) as.data.frame(lapply(iris.e.agg, unlist), col.names=colnames(iris.e.agg)) ##      Species Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width ## 1     setosa       5.0(1)     3.43(7)      1.46(3)     0.25(1) ## 2 versicolor       5.9(1)     2.77(6)      4.26(9)     1.33(3) ## 3  virginica       6.6(1)     2.97(6)       5.6(1)     2.03(4)

title: Measurement Errors in R
text: introduced , lightweight R package managing numeric data associated standard uncertainties. new class provides numeric operations automated propagation uncertainty first-order TSM, formally sound representation measurements errors. Using package makes process computing indirect measurements easier less error-prone. Future work includes importing exporting data uncertainties providing user interface plugging uncertainty propagation methods packages. Finally, enables ongoing developments integrating uncertainty handling complete solution quantity calculus. unified workflow managing measurements units errors interesting addition R ecosystem precedents programming languages.

Every errors object unique ID, pairwise correlations stored internal hash table. functions methods modify somehow dimensions errors objects (.e., subsets, binds, concatenations, summaries...) generate new objects new IDs, correlations , , propagated. mathematical arithmetic operations propagate correlations, appropriate, following Taylor series method.

title: Handle Correlations Between errors Objects — correl
code: x <- set_errors(1:5, 0.1) y <- set_errors(1:5, 0.1)  # Self-correlation is of course 1, and cannot be changed correl(x, x) #> [1] 1 1 1 1 1 if (FALSE) { correl(x, x) <- 0.5}  # Cross-correlation can be set, but must be a value between -1 and 1 correl(x, y) #> NULL if (FALSE) { correl(x, y) <- 1.5} correl(x, y) <- runif(length(x)) correl(x, y) #> [1] 0.55258077 0.75646363 0.46660548 0.04901938 0.17421861 covar(x, y) #> [1] 0.0055258077 0.0075646363 0.0046660548 0.0004901938 0.0017421861

title: Datasets from the Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement (GUM) — datasets
text: GUM.H.2, Section 2 Annex H (Table H.2), provides simultaneous resistance reactance measurements. data frame 5 rows 3 variables: V Voltage amplitude, Volts. Current amplitude, Amperes. phi Phase-shift angle voltage relative current, radians. GUM.H.3, Section 3 Annex H (Table H.6), provides thermometer readings observed corrections obtain linear calibration curve reference temperature. data frame 11 rows 2 variables: tk Thermometer reading, Celsius degrees. bk Observed correction, Celsius degrees. object class data.frame 11 rows 2 columns.

title: errors: Uncertainty Propagation for R Vectors — errors-package
text: Every measurement unknown error associated. Uncertainty acknowledgement error: aware representation reality may differ reality . package provides support measurement errors R vectors, matrices arrays. Uncertainty metadata associated quantity values (see errors), uncertainty automatically propagated operate errors objects (see groupGeneric.errors), errors numeric objects (numeric values automatically coerced errors objects uncertainty). Correlations measurements also supported. particular, operation (e.g., z <- x + y) results correlation output input variables (.e., z correlated x y, even correlation x y). general, user can establish correlations pair variables (see correl). package treats uncertainty coming Gaussian linear sources (note , even non-Gaussian non-linear sources, reasonable assumption averages many measurements), propagates using first-order Taylor series method propagation uncertainty. Although assumptions valid wide range applications science engineering, practitioner evaluate whether apply particular case.

title: errors: Uncertainty Propagation for R Vectors — errors-package
text: Iñaki Ucar

title: errors: Uncertainty Propagation for R Vectors — errors-package
code: ## Simultaneous resistance and reactance measurements  # Obtain mean values and uncertainty from measured values V   <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$V)) I   <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$I)) phi <- mean(set_errors(GUM.H.2$phi))  # Set correlations between variables correl(V, I)   <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(V, I)) correl(V, phi) <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(V, phi)) correl(I, phi) <- with(GUM.H.2, cor(I, phi))  # Computation of resistance, reactance and impedance values (R <- (V / I) * cos(phi)) #> 127.73(7) (X <- (V / I) * sin(phi)) #> 219.8(3) (Z <- (V / I)) #> 254.3(2)  # Correlations between derived quantities correl(R, X) #> [1] -0.5884298 correl(R, Z) #> [1] -0.4852592 correl(X, Z) #> [1] 0.9925116  ## Calibration of a thermometer  # Least-squares fit for a reference temperature of 20 degC fit <- lm(bk ~ I(tk - 20), data = GUM.H.3)  # Extract coefficients and set correlation using the covariance matrix y1 <- set_errors(coef(fit)[1], sqrt(vcov(fit)[1, 1])) y2 <- set_errors(coef(fit)[2], sqrt(vcov(fit)[2, 2])) covar(y1, y2) <- vcov(fit)[1, 2]  # Predicted correction for 30 degC (b.30 <- y1 + y2 * set_errors(30 - 20)) #> -0.149(4)

FALSE never includes, TRUE always includes. can also named logical vector finely select aesthetics display. inherit.aes FALSE, overrides default aesthetics, rather combining . useful helper functions define data aesthetics inherit behaviour default plot specification, e.g. borders().

title: Errorbars for errors objects — geom_errors
code: if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly=TRUE)) {  iris.e <- iris iris.e[1:4] <- lapply(iris.e[1:4], function(x) set_errors(x, x*0.02))  library(ggplot2)  ggplot(iris.e) + aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color=Species) +   geom_point() + geom_errors()  ggplot(iris.e) + aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color=Species) +   geom_point() + geom_errors(width=0.05, height=0.05, size=0.2)  } #> Warning: In '<' : boolean operators not defined for 'errors' objects, uncertainty dropped #> Warning: Using the `size` aesthetic in this geom was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` in the `default_aes` field and elsewhere instead.

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
text: Math, Ops Summary group generic methods errors objects support automatic uncertainty propagation (see groupGeneric comprehensive list available methods).

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
code: # S3 method for errors Math(x, ...)  # S3 method for errors Ops(e1, e2)  # S3 method for errors Summary(..., na.rm = FALSE)

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
text: x, e1, e2 objects. ... arguments passed methods. na.rm logical: missing values removed?

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
text: sign method returns numeric value without uncertainty. floor, ceiling, trunc, round signif add rounding error original uncertainty. lgamma, gamma, digamma trigamma implemented. rest methods propagate uncertainty expected first-order Taylor series method.

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
text: Boolean operators drop uncertainty (showing warning ) operate numeric values. rest operators propagate uncertainty expected first-order Taylor series method. numeric operand automatically coerced errors (showing warning ) uncertainty.

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
text: methods supported errors objects fail informative message. min, max (range) return minimum () maximum value minus/plus uncertainty. sum prod propagate uncertainty expected first-order Taylor series method.

title: S3 Group Generic Functions — groupGeneric.errors
code: x <- set_errors(1:3, 0.1) exp(x) #> Errors: 0.2718282 0.7389056 2.0085537 #> [1]  2.718282  7.389056 20.085537 log(x) #> Errors: 0.10000000 0.05000000 0.03333333 #> [1] 0.0000000 0.6931472 1.0986123 cumsum(x) #> Errors: 0.1000000 0.1414214 0.1732051 #> [1] 1 3 6 cumprod(x) #> Errors: 0.1000000 0.2236068 0.7000000 #> [1] 1 2 6  y <- set_errors(4:6, 0.2) x / sqrt(y) + y * sin(x) #> Errors: 0.3083702 0.2314527 0.5532258 #> [1] 3.865884 5.440914 2.071465  # numeric values are automatically coerced to errors x^2 #> Warning: In 'Ops' : non-'errors' operand automatically coerced to an 'errors' object with no uncertainty #> Errors: 0.2 0.4 0.6 #> [1] 1 4 9  # boolean operators drop uncertainty y > x #> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE  c(min(x), max(x)) #> [1] 0.9 3.1 range(x) #> [1] 0.9 3.1 sum(y) #> 15.0(3) prod(y) #> 120(9)

title: errors 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-12-04 Add new geom_errors() function automatically add errorbars ggplot2 plots variables class errors (#52). fixes plot.errors, improved units compatibility. Implement errors methods duplicated, anyDuplicated unique. Fix operators %/% %% (#54).

title: errors 0.3.6
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-10 Fix check tolerance correlations approx. 1 (#42).

title: errors 0.3.5
text: CRAN release: 2020-08-26 Internal performance improvements (#39).

title: errors 0.3.4
text: CRAN release: 2020-06-13 vctrs methods now implemented compatibility dplyr 1.0 (#38). Implement prettier str print (#36). Implement drop method data frames.

title: errors 0.3.3
text: CRAN release: 2020-01-08 Fix min, max range (#35). Rewrite plot fix issues limits labels (#35).

title: errors 0.3.2
text: CRAN release: 2019-05-20 Add CITATION R Journal paper. Add paper vignette.

title: errors 0.3.1
text: CRAN release: 2018-12-05

title: errors 0.3.1
text: Add new dataset Annex H Guide Expression Uncertainty Measurement (GUM) associated example (f6e5461, see ?GUM.H.3). Provide methods logical values automatically reinterpret NA NA_real_ (#30). Add delayed S3 registration mechanism R >= 3.6.0 (955e7ad).

title: errors 0.3.1
text: Move GUM examples ?`errors-package` provide new examples ?correl (aed40eb). Simplify object ID handling (#27). Fix formatting presence missing values (part #30). Fix Summary.errors deal named arguments (dd4607b).

title: errors 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2018-07-26

title: errors 0.3.0
text: Implement .list errors objects (7aff546). Implement support correlations variables (#26). correl covar methods set retrieve pairwise correlations covariances, respectively, errors objects, thereby completing full first-order Taylor series method propagation uncertainty. Add new dataset Annex H Guide Expression Uncertainty Measurement (GUM) (part #26; see ?GUM.H.2 examples ?correl). Implement .equal errors objects (part #26), returns TRUE different (different internal identifier) objects quantity values uncertainty. compare whether two variables exactly object, identical used instead.

title: errors 0.3.0
text: Fix encoding issues plus-minus symbol (#24). Fix pillar representation (14df89b). Fix coercion issues (0e04519). Improve documentation (part #26).

title: errors 0.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2018-04-03

title: errors 0.2.1
text: New drop_errors method drops errors class attributes. Equivalent setting NULL error (#23). Implement pillar_shaft tidy tibble printing improve type_sum (700f1aa).

title: errors 0.2.1
text: Show Ops warnings (#22). Refactor print method (2c252d9). Drop support matrix multiplication: warning issued anymore (090e953). Fix cbind/rbind column/row name parsing named arguments (b8ea6b5). Improve plus-minus separator (8b3d231). Fix formatting take account scipen option (9299551).

title: errors 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2017-11-26

title: errors 0.2.0
text: Show warning drop errors boolean operators instead failing (#17). min, max, range return numeric, including error: value minus error, value plus error (min, max) respectively (#18). Use structure instead set_errors internally (#20). Improved support matrices data frames implementation rbind, cbind, .data.frame errors objects (#21). Improved documentation testing (#19).

title: errors 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2017-09-26

title: errors 0.1.0
text: Improved support arrays matrices (#4). Inf, NaN NA values default Inf, NaN NA errors respectively (#10). Drop errors warning matrix multiplication (#11). Fix errors defined integers (#12). allow boolean operators errors objects (#13). Give default value set_errors (#14). Tidy tibble printing (#15). Correct plot limits according error bars (#16).

title: errors 0.0.2
text: CRAN release: 2017-06-07

title: errors 0.0.2
text: Fix exponentiation negative base (#2). Fix formatting value equals zero (#3). Fix formatting error equals zero (#5). Take digits account errors vector display (#7). Fix deletion trailing zeroes plus-minus notation (#8).
